stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you explain how an anaesthetic vaporizer works, and why desflurane requires a special vaporizer?

prompts.text: Describe the principles of a plenum vaporizer.
expectedKeyFacts: Variable bypass vaporizer (e.g., Tec 5 for isoflurane, sevoflurane)
Fresh gas flow splits into bypass and vaporizing chamber
Dial controls splitting ratio
Vaporizing chamber saturated with vapour at SVP
Temperature compensation: bimetallic strip adjusts flow
Accurate delivery over wide range of flows and temperatures
Agent-specific: calibrated for one volatile agent

prompts.text: Why does desflurane require a heated, pressurized vaporizer?
expectedKeyFacts: Desflurane boiling point 23.5°C — near room temperature
Would boil at normal operating room temperatures
High saturated vapour pressure at 20°C (669 mmHg or 88 kPa)
Standard vaporizer cannot accurately control delivery
TEC 6 vaporizer: heated to 39°C, pressurized to 2 bar (1500 mmHg)
Creates predictable vapour pressure regardless of ambient temperature
Electronic control and fresh gas blending
Requires electrical power

prompts.text: What safety features are built into modern vaporizers?
expectedKeyFacts: Agent-specific keyed fillers — prevent filling with wrong agent
Interlock system — only one vaporizer can be turned on at a time
Overfill protection — prevents overfilling which would alter output
Temperature compensation maintains accuracy
Desflurane vaporizer: alarms for low agent, low battery, overpressure
Cannot be tipped when full — damages wicks and calibration
Colour-coded: sevoflurane yellow, isoflurane purple, desflurane blue

prompts.text: A vaporizer is accidentally tipped over with agent inside. What problems might occur?
expectedKeyFacts: Liquid agent enters bypass chamber
Delivers excessive concentration — risk of overdose
Wicks become damaged or displaced
Temperature compensation disrupted
Calibration lost
Management: remove from use, drain completely, send for service/recalibration
Do NOT use until serviced
Use alternative vaporizer if available
Document incident

prompts.text: Compare the advantages and disadvantages of desflurane versus sevoflurane.
expectedKeyFacts: Desflurane: lowest blood:gas coefficient (0.42) — fastest onset/offset
Rapid emergence and titration
Pungent — unsuitable for gas induction, airway irritation
Requires expensive heated vaporizer, needs electricity
High environmental impact — potent greenhouse gas
Sevoflurane: pleasant odour, suitable for gas induction
Slower offset than desflurane but faster than isoflurane
Compound A formation with soda lime
Both expensive agents compared to isoflurane

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me what happens inside a vaporizer when you turn the dial — how does it control the concentration delivered?
keyFacts: TEC 6: heated to 39°C, pressurized to 2 bar
Safety: keyed fillers, interlock, overfill protection
Tipping damages calibration — remove from service
Desflurane: fastest offset, pungent, needs heated vaporizer
Sevoflurane: pleasant, suitable for induction, forms Compound A

scoringGuidance.pass: Describes plenum vaporizer principles with bypass and vaporizing chamber, explains why desflurane needs special vaporizer (BP 23.5°C, high SVP), knows safety features including keyed fillers, understands risks of tipping, compares desflurane and sevoflurane; stronger candidates discuss temperature compensation mechanism and environmental impact
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows vaporizer splits gas flow but mechanism unclear, aware desflurane is different but reasons vague, mentions some safety features, unclear on tipping risks
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot describe vaporizer principle, does not know why desflurane is special, unaware of safety features or risks of tipping, cannot compare volatile agents
